comments.commentBody: Don't apologize for speaking the truth, what you say must be said. I volunteer as a mentor to inner city youth, many of whom are African American, and the lack of skilled parenting, particularly fathers is clearly the key factor. If you look at the programs that are successful at educating kids from very poor white or african American families, you will see that they do so by so dominating the childs time that they in effect fill in for the inadequat parenting skills. Is this what it will take, the state stepping in to parent kids from single parent families? Throwing money into these broken families more often just creates a new generation of the same. How do we stop this cycle?

The trick is not fatherhood so much as fathers with jobs who can make a real contribution to supporting a family. The farther down the income ladder you go, the harder it is to find men with the economic where with all to support themselves , much less a family. Recent studies show that it is now upper income individuals who are getting married (although they are marrying after getting their educations) and staying married. It's all about getting a decent job.

I agree.  I taught in one of the poorest schools and in one of the wealthiest schools and I was struck by the fact that the kids who succeeded (rich or poor) had a good strong family AND a parent who participated in the school (going to parent-teacher conferences, etc.).   The other factor is the poor families who had many children and little money usually lived in a chaotic home with a great deal of stress and lack of support for the children.  Rich kids, whose parents worked 24/7 and were too busy to attend school functions, do have resources (like tutors and college consultants) to assist their kids.  However, they suffered in other ways-- drugs and behavior problems.  We can do all we want in the schools but what really matters is for a child to have an advocate who cares about them and puts in the time to help them, preferably a parent.

As someone who has worked in education at all levels, including college, it never ceases to amaze me that most people do not see the obvious. Yes, of course the wealthiest give their children the best education. Likewise, the poor receive the worst. However, the factor that is linked to each is FATHERHOOD. Families with fathers are wealthier than those without. Those communities that have discounted the importance of fathers- particularly the black communities- suffer economically and educationally, and not even because schools lack money. No school I have ever worked in has ever been without books, computers etc. The difference among them is the discipline of the students and the expectations of their parents. Homes without fathers are typically more likely to produce children whose behavior and discipline suffer. These are not opinions that are P.C. or ones that I wish to hold, but just some I have developed after years of observation.

Beware a growing rat problem with on-site composting in cities. Not every super understands or is willing to comply with trash regulations now - one still sees trash stored on the ground instead of in containers - let alone proper composting; that decomposition smell will attract rats for blocks.

The average weight  of compost is about 35 pounds per month for two people . The compost generates heat and breaks down into fine soil very rapidly. I believe it takes decades for soil to naturally form. Compost has a sweet smell   when maintained with moisture and air. Cities with much less population density could encourage composting on site without moving it to a central location.and reduce fuel consumption for  garbage pickup.

"Children do not start school until age 7."

This would be absolutely devastating to working class and middle class American families. Daycare for one kid can easily - easily - eat up half a paycheck for a full-time worker. Most of us can't wait to get our kids into all day kindergarten at age five to get some relief from the crushing expense.

Also, Finland has two teachers in every classroom!! One to teach, and one to move around and help kids who are having trouble. Having two teachers in the classroom also helps with disciplinary problems. Our school hasn't got the money for two teachers, but if we have disciplinary problems with a class, we try to stick another teacher in to monitor. Works like a charm.
In any case, what Finland does costs money, and no one in the US seems to want to put their money where their mouth is. Ultimately the folks in power don't really care about how poor minority kids are doing.
There is also a huge social welfare net that prevents the psychological and biological distortions of poverty.  It ain't just educational policy, So-krates!

Just dump everything American education does and plagiarize from Finland's educational playbook.

The Finnish school system uses the same curriculum for all students.

Students have light homework loads.

Finnish schools do not have classes for gifted students.

Finland uses very little standardized testing.

Children do not start school until age 7.

Finland has a comprehensive preschool program that emphasizes "self-reflection" and socializing, not academics.

Grades are not given until high school, and even then, class rankings are not compiled.

Teachers must have master's degrees.

Becoming a teacher in Finland is highly competitive. Just 10% of Finnish college graduates are accepted into the teacher training program; as a result, teaching is a high-status profession. (Teacher salaries are similar to teacher salaries in the U.S., however.)

Students are separated into academic and vocational tracks during the last three years of high school. About 50% go into each track.

Diagnostic testing of students is used early and frequently. If a student is in need of extra help, intensive intervention is provided.

Groups of teachers visit each others' classes to observe their colleagues at work.

Teachers also get one afternoon per week for professional development.

School funding is higher for the middle school years, the years when children are most in danger of dropping out.

College is free in Finland.

American education is national disgrace.

"Bill and Hillary Clinton are not progressives." In his presidency, Bill was certainly centrist, not progressive. But in her 2008 presidential campaign, Hilary was by far a more progressive--and yes, liberal--candidate than Obama. Overall Obama had the more soaring rhetoric and ran a better campaign, so he deserved to win. I think a lot of liberals & progressives were taken in by the youthful appeal of Obama and saw in him what they wanted to see. But if you really listened to what Barack Obama & Hillary Clinton said in the 2008 primaries, it was clear she was the real progressive in the race--or at least the only real progressive with a chance to win.I kept wondering why progressives were so frustrated at Obama's (mostly futile) attempts to compromise with Republicans. Didn't he say he would do that a few thousand times in the 2008 campaign? So, Hillary may not be the most progressive politician out there, but in 2008 she sure ran as a more progressive candidate than the president we have now.

Nothing has been done to mitigate, in any way, the losses the economy will have to bear, not to mention the personal loss of each and every one of them arising from losing their careers and no longer contributing to society.

Then, there are the homeless. The editorial tonight is about New York City's homeless, which the new mayor will have to deal with. New York City is hardly alone in having a sizable homeless population. These are the true victims of the Great Recession. No one ever talks about them. They're in every city, big and small. They're young, middle-aged, elderly, single, in families with children. What about them?

Agree. Critical thinking can't happen unless you have a basis for criticism. Until you have at least a basic set of knowledge and skills, no matter what the subject, how can you do critical thinking? It's a lot like Jimmy Kimmel's asking people's opinions on nonsensical topics - everybody's got an opinion, but nobody has the right facts.
Arithmetic (drill and kill) has to come first. Developing algorithms and testing them against proven algorithms could be a lesson in critical thinking - but knowing the proven algorithms comes first.
Your experience is exactly what the curriculum designers should be thinking about.  But do they ask teachers?

One of the basic dilemmas in the teaching of K - 12 mathematics is how to balance algorithmic facility with critical thinking. Common Core is likely to put in relief this issue. It is pretty hard to teach critical thinking in Algebra I if the kids have trouble with their multiplication tables. I had three Algebra I classes last year and the lack of understanding of the fundamentals (e.g. operations with fractions, order of operations and working with proportions) made it impossible to find time to develop critical thinking - I had to go back to the fundamentals.  As stark and politically incorrect as it sounds, drill and kill has its place in education (and not only in mathematics), just as critical thinking does.
